statement: The method seems to rely heavily on the 'exact velocity' from (Ryzhakov et al., 2024); however, both the motivation and details of this need more development.
More comparison (especially numerical results) to previous works is needed, as other approaches that bypass inference integration, like consistency models, are not mentioned in the related work.

It is rather unclear what a prototype is, whether it is the point in Z one would converge to if there are no errors in ODE solver, or whether a prototype can be any point in Z that you happen to converge to.

When prototypes are found in the source distribution, noise is first added to the position in the target distribution, but the motivation for this is hardly satisfactory despite almost a full page trying to argue why the added noise is necessary.
It is unclear how tolerance and sigma interact and why sigma is needed - from the presented theory, sigma would not be needed, but without sigma, only very poor prototypes are learned.
No evaluation and comparison of the computational efficiency of the generative model is offered, which is the main motivation of the approach for eliminating ODE solving during sampling.
It is unclear how the single-step sampling actually works since the method still requires solving the ODE to find prototypes during training.
More experiments for more complex target distributions beyond the tested datasets would be needed to demonstrate the method's generalizability.
More detail is needed for the color transfer task on the Winter2Summer dataset and comparison to other color transfer methods both quantitatively and qualitatively.
